passages.text: Friday, 29 August 2025
Top Call | MENA | South Africa | Emerging Europe | Sector | Strategy & Economics | Fixed Income & FX | Key Rating and Target Price Changes

We initiated on Emaar Properties with a Buy rating in Jun'25 as we expected the strong UAE property sales momentum from 2024/1Q25 to persist despite the ongoing concerns around oversupply in the real estate market. Emaar's stock price is up c.8.5% over the past three months, as the developer reported robust operating trends for 2Q25. We believe recent trends could continue in the M.T. Reiterate Buy. New TP AED 18.50. We also close a short- term catalyst watch opened into 2Q reporting.
Rahul Bajaj, CFA | Nitesh Agarwal

With Talabat's shares down \(20\%\) in the last 3 months, underperforming DFMG1 by 30pp (u/p by \(\sim 50\) pp since IPO in Dec- 24), we see current valuations fairly reflecting a more competitive environment. The key catalysts flagged in our initiation have largely played out: we saw Keeta's expansion to Talabat's markets (Qatar launched, UAE/Kuwait likely coming soon); Talabat started to revise its margin guidance after 2Q25 (FY25 guidance implies \(\sim 0.5\) pp margin decline in 2H25 vs. 1H25); the market is now pricing \(\sim 4.5 - 5\%\) LT EBITDA/GMV margin, in line with our expectations. Our estimates and AED1.2 TP are unchanged, now implying a positive TSR, hence we upgrade the stock to Neutral. We also provide key takeaways from Meituan's 2Q25 profit warning and DHER's 2Q25 results.
Delivery Hero SE (HER.DE) - Solid 1H25 results with \(7\%\) adj. EBITDA beat, but FY25e adj. EBUDA downgraded \(8\%\) at mid- point

Solid 1H25 results, but material FY25e downgrade. Q2 GMV growth of \(+9.4\%\) ex- hyperinflation (1Q25: \(+8\%\) ) with GMV in- line with company- compiled consensus. Asia was slightly better than expected, but Americas worse - Figure 1. 1H25 Adj. EBITDA of €410.7m is a \(7\%\) beat driven by better profitability in Asia and

Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Certain products (not inconsistent with the author's published research) are available only on Citi's portals.

the Americas, with MENA and Europe worse - Figure 2. 1H25 FCFF (company definition) was - €8m (Citi - €32m) given EBITDA beat. On Saudi order growth, management comments it remains \(>20\%\) YoY in 2Q25, 1Q25 order growth of \(>20\%\) YoY (but with 2- 3p drag from Ramadan). 2025 adj. EBITDA guidance downgraded - 8% at the mid- point; FY25e Adj. EBITDA €900- 940m including €110m FX headwinds (previously €975- 1,025m; 1H25: €411m; consensus €993m; Citi €974m) and FCFF (company definition) \(>€120m\) including €80m FX headwinds (previously \(>€200m\) ; consensus €217m, Citi €196m). We expect a negative share- price reaction with the FY25e adj. EBITDA guidance implying 2H25e EBITDA - 16%...
Monique Pollard | Jamie Bass | Vandita Sood | Elizabeth Moore
Impala Platinum (IMPJ.J) - FY25 HEPS in line with trading update; dividend a beat; FY26 guidance weaker vs CitiE

FY25 HEPS declined - 69% y/y to ZAR0.82/sh, in line with the trading update (FY24: ZAR2.7/sh, CitiE: ZAR4.5/sh, VA Consensus: ZAR4.4/sh). EBITDA declined by - 20% y/y. The y/y decline was primarily due to lower volume sold (- 2%), higher unit costs (7%); among other factors. FCF remained positive and resulted in net cash increasing further to ZAR8.1bn (equivalent to c6% of market cap). A net cash position and recent strength in rand basket prices likely resulted in company announcing a dividend of ZAR1.65/sh implying a payout of 2.0x. As previously announced, concentrate production declined by - 3% y/y to 3.55moz, broadly in line with CitiE. Lower sales volume resulted in 30koz inventory increase to 420koz at FY25 end (unplanned furnace maintenance and utility supply disruptions). The company also announced guidance for FY26 which is weaker vs CitiE. Ephrem Ravi | Shashi Shekhar, CFA | Krishan M Agarwal
Ephrem Ravi | Shashi Shekhar, CFA | Krishan M Agarwal

1H25 HEPS increased to ZAR1.9/sh (1H24: ZAR0.05/sh) on a lower base and came in line vs the trading statement range. EBITDA increased by 127% y/y to ZAR15.1bn. The y/y increase is primarily due to (i) higher gold prices, (ii) S45X advanced manufacturing production credits, and (iii) reduced losses from US PGM ops, partially offset by operational constraints at SA PGM/gold ops that led to inventory build and lower sales, and other factors. Free cash flow turned positive and balance sheet improved to cZAR21bn (incl Burnstone), implying a net debt to EBIDA of c0.7x (based on annualized EBITDA). The company announced no interim dividend, in line with our expectations. FY25 guidance except for gold remain unchanged (gold production - 6% while AISC +6%).
Ephrem Ravi | Shashi Shekhar, CFA | Krishan M Agarwal
Truworths International Ltd (TRUJ.J) - Well- guided, but post- period trade tracking softer than our and cons FY 26 est

Truworths released a well- guided result with HEPS coming in at R7.52 missing Cons R7.93 and Citi: R8.15). We think the stock is likely to react negatively to this update given the soft post- period trade for the group: - 0.1% vs Citi FY 26e: 6.7% and cons: 7.29% (First 7 wks TRU Africa: - 3.1% and Office UK: 3.4%). This could result in downgrades to full year estimates. This is despite the stock trading on trailing PE of 8.7x below 5 yr ave of 9.0x. We think the poor sales performance in TRU Africa in H2 25 hampered any opportunity to grow profits, despite better GPM. Thus, further sales declines presents downside to risk to profits in TRU Africa in FY 26e. Office UK delivered a pleasant profitability, although missing by 5% on EBIT. Softer start to FY 26e, could pressure profits and margins n FY 26e as well.

Yesterday (Aug. 28) at the 2Q25 analyst call, PUZ's CFO Tomasz Kulik disclosed that the internal risk model should be introduced by PUZ by the end of 2026 - i.e., before the new version of the Solvency ZW will come into force (the beginning of 2027) - and should significantly offset the negative impact of the new Solvency 2 on PUZ's capital ratio. Mr. Kulik expects that due to internal model implementation in the status quo scenario (no creation of the HoldCo and no merger with Pekao), PUZ's Solvency 2 ratio would not decline below \(200\%\) in 2027.

In 2Q25, CD Projekt reported net profit of ZL 69m (- 1yoy, - 20% qoq), which came \(8\%\) above PAP consensus and \(36\%\) above our estimates with effective tax of \(21\%\) . Revenues of ZL 217m were \(+9\%\) yoy and came \(+5\% / + 2\%\) vs. consensus and our expectation. EBIT came in at ZL 72m (+23% yoy) and was \(27\% /63\%\) above consensus and our estimates with EBIT margin of \(33.4\%\) vs. \(- 28\%\) market expected. Expenditure on new projects came in high at ZL 142m (+150% yoy, \(+43\%\) qoq). Net cash position stood at ZL 1.43bn, \(- 4\%\) qoq. OCF was reported at ZL \(- 98m\) , \(+41\%\) yoy, \(- 35\%\) qoq. Number of developers increased by \(9\%\) qoq to 799 with \(56\%\) working on W4.

Eurocash reported 2Q25 EBITDA of ZL 229m (flat yoy or \(+5\%\) yoy on revised 2Q24) that came \(- 3\%\) above consensus and \(- 13\%\) vs. Citi. The company reported net loss of ZL 13.5m vs. ZL 4.6m PAP expected profit (on high net fin. costs). Revenues of ZL 7.88bn (- 4% yoy or \(- 1\%\) on restated 2Q24) came \(5\%\) short of consensus and \(- 2\%\) vs. Citi. LFL sales came in soft with just \(+1\%\) in the retail segment and very weak \(- 11.5\%\) in the wholesale segment. Gross margin was \(- 0.26\) pp yoy at \(12.84\%\) (visibly below our expected \(13.45\%\) ). However, SG&A costs surprised positively coming at \(- 8\%\) yoy and \(- 5\%\) vs. Citi. OCF was \(- 11\%\) yoy in 2Q and \(- 9\%\) in 1H. Overall numbers look mixed to us, disappointing at profit, sales and LFL levels with positive surprise on the cost front.

SXAP 12m forward EBIT estimates are now \(- 50\%\) off their 5Y highs following two major profit warning cycles in 2H24/1H25. While EU autos remain deeply exposed to a number of cyclical/structural problems, we think many of these are now parsed into both consensus estimates and valuations. While we do not expect a rapid reversal in margins or sentiment, we do think i) sequential margins can improve in FY26E, and ii) relative EPS momentum has found its floor. Very low expectations, tariff certainty, 'less bad' EPS momentum, strategic dialogue on EU CO2 rules and increased restructuring savings FY26 vs 25 create positive risk- reward into seasonally stronger year- end, in our view. We continue to see Volkswagen and Porsche as good ways to position from here, sticking with our Buy ratings. The key risk remains any credit/macro deterioration moving into 2H25.
Harald C Hendrikse | Ross MacDonald | Soumava Banerjee

We saw very little changes to broad positioning during August. Asset allocators remain long equities and underweight USD. Changes were limited mostly to position trimming this month. The bearish USD positioning remained intact despite the greenback's strength. Other consensus underweights are in fixed income; both USTs and JGBs. Overweight positions include EM rates, US real rates, and Gilts while credit remains in relative value mode, underweight US IG and overweight EU high yield. Managers are overweight the commodity complex, with gold a consensus trade; the biggest change on the month was increased energy exposure (from neutral). Consensus FX positions remain; long EUR and EMFX against short USD. Manager disagreement exists in US equities, now neutral, and US HY credit. Most managers with a view are short Japan bonds and IG credit. There continues to be very little to no disagreement in consensus FX views.
Alex Saunders | Nathaniel Rupert | Dirk Willer | Alice Zheng | Adam Pickett

The NVDA quarter suggests that the US Al boom continues. We remain overweight US equities but had tactically taken profits in our TWSE long ahead of the print. We would add additional equity risk on a seasonal September pull- back. We add USDCLP topside to our radar heading into the Latam election season. We reiterate our paid 1y1y in Japan, in line with BoJ Governor Ueda's Jackson Hole speech. We recently added to both steepeners and USD shorts given rising risks of a more dovish FOMC in case of a Lisa Cook exit. We think continued political risks in France will not impact EUR much but can more easily be positioned for in the equity space.
Adam Pickett | Dirk Willer | Giammarco Miani | Charlie Massy- Collier | Alice Zheng

US \(16.6bn\) inflow into equity funds - In the week of 27 August 2025, US \(19.7bn\) of inflow went into bond funds while equity funds had US \(16.6bn\) . Global funds saw US \(5.8bn\) of inflow. US funds also had US \(8.5bn\) of flows coming back in. European funds however were hit by US \(1.2bn\) of net redemptions. In Japan, equity funds saw US \(0.9bn\) of outflow while their Money Market funds saw similarly sized inflows.
Chris Ma | Yue Hin Pong | Chris Montagu | Hong Li

Markets are adjusting to dovish signals from the Fed, but price action is choppy, raising questions about positive EM risk positions. We believe US rates can adjust further, allowing for positive EMFX developments. That said, a stubborn 5- 30s steepening bias may persist. EMFX carry strategies remain positive, cushioned by interest rate differentials. Key economic data over the next few weeks may suggest a Fed cut in September, but the US economy could reflate faster than expected, challenging EM assets. Our view remains positive interest rate risk in EM, supported by EMFX contributions to total returns in portfolios. We remain positive on EM interest rate risk, expecting EMFX to contribute to portfolio returns. Reduced net non- commercial VIX contracts suggest potential vulnerability to a US equity risk correction. Constructive energy inflation contribution is expected to remain dominant until the beginning of 2026.
Luis E Costa, CFA | Rohit Garg | Donato Guarino | Bhumika Gupta | Alexander Rozhetskin

Macro view: The vote of confidence that will take place on \(8^{\text{th}}\) September in France creates considerable uncertainty. Political instability and policy opacity that have prevailed since summer 2024 would likely persist. It would most likely continue to put widening pressure on EGB spreads. We believe a snap election is partly in the price but could still lead to OAT spreads widening towards 90- 95bp. Equity Strategy: For French equities this could imply further \(c5\%\) downside. In a more extreme scenario of President Macron resigning, spreads could move to 120- 125bp, implying over \(10\%\) downside risk for French equities. Alternatively, the government surviving or a new PM being elected without election could imply some upside. Sector/Stock impacts: We survey Citi equity analysts on the potential sector and stock- level implications of an election.
Beata M Manthey, Ph.D. | David Groman | Nikhil N Jadhav, CFA | Arnaud Marès | Giada Giani
The Week Ahead presents our forecast for CEEMEA's economic data due to be released in the upcoming week.
Gina Schoeman | David Cowan | Ilker Domac | Piotr Kalisz, CFA | Michel Nies

The government is planning 2026 fiscal deficit at \(6.5\%\) of GDP. This plan implies deficit reduction as compared to 2025, but the forecast assumes the rise in excise taxes and CIT, despite the risk of them being vetoed by the president. In our view, the new budget draft underscores challenges faced by the Polish government, including the need to maintain high defense spending despite limited space to increase taxes. The budget draft does not change much in the inflation trajectory and still leaves some space for rate cuts, but we see the risk that the MPC may turn hawkish anyway and be tempted to spread easing over a longer time. Higher public debt path means also that now the focus will shift towards rating agencies that are expected to review Poland's rating in the next three months.
Piotr Kalisz, CFA | Arkadiusz Trzciolek

Sentiment held up in manufacturing (we think for temporary reasons) while eased among consumers and services firms, potentially undermining the timid private consumption recovery. Price pressures in the services sector suggest limited downside on services HICP inflation in the coming months.

We expect around €29bn of EGB supply next week, from scheduled issuance (Germany, France, Spain and Belgium). The UK DMO will issue an estimated £11.25bn of gilts including IL45. There is no UST supply.

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

Investment Ratings: Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of 15% or more or 25% or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient

valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "-" and "-" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re- establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short- term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in reaction to one or more specific near- term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds 15% against the direction of the call (unless over- ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer- term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings- distribution- disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution- disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share- price movement will not materialize as expected.
Any price(s) of instruments mentioned in recommendations are as of the prior day's market close on the primary market for the instrument, unless otherwise stated.

The completion and first dissemination of any recommendations made within this research report are as of the Eastern date- time displayed at the top of the Product. If the Product references views of other analysts then please refer to the price chart or rating history table for the date/time of completion and first dissemination with respect to that view.

Regulations in various jurisdictions require that where a recommendation differs from any of the author's previous recommendations concerning the same financial instrument or issuer that has been published during the preceding 12- month period that the change(s) and the date of that previous recommendation are indicated. For fundamental coverage please refer to the price chart or rating change history within this disclosure appendix or the issuer disclosure summary at https://www.citvlicocity.com/cvr/ppublic/citi_research_disclosures.

Citi Research has implemented policies for identifying, considering and managing potential conflicts of interest arising as a result of publication or distribution of investment research. A description of these policies can be found at https://www.citvlicocity.com/cvr/ppublic/citi_research_disclosures.

The proportion of all Citi Research research recommendations that were the equivalent to "Buy", "Hold", "Sell" at the end of each quarter over the prior 12 months (with the % of these that had received investment firm services from Citi in the prior 12 months shown in brackets) is as follows: Q2 2025 Buy 33% (63%), Hold 44% (51%), Sell 23% (49%), RV 0.4% (86%); Q1 2025 Buy 33% (63%), Hold 44% (51%), Sell 23% (49%), RV 0.5% (87%); Q4 2024 Buy 32% (64%), Hold 44% (52%), Sell 23% (44%), RV 0.4% (92%); Q3 2024 Buy 33% (61%), Hold 44% (52%), Sell 23% (49%), RV 0.4% (80%). For the purposes of disclosing recommendations other than for equity (whose definitions can be found in the corresponding disclosure sections), "Buy" means a positive directional trade idea; "Sell" means a negative directional trade idea; and "Relative Value" means any trade idea which does not have a clear direction to the investment strategy.

European regulations require a 5 year price history when past performance of a security is referenced. CitiVelocity's Charting Tool (https://www.citvlicocity.com/cv2/#go/CHARTING_3_Equities) provides the facility to create customisable price charts including a five year option. This tool can be found in the Data & Analytics section under any of the asset class menus in CitiVelocity (https://www.citvlicocity.com/). For further information contact CitiVelocity support (https://www.citvlicocity.com/cv2/go/CLIENT_SUPPORT). The source for all referenced prices, unless otherwise stated, is DataCentral, which sources price information from Thomson Reuters. Past performance is not a guarantee or reliable indicator of future results. Forecasts are not a guarantee or reliable indicator of future performance.

Notwithstanding other departments within the Firm advising the companies discussed in this Product, information obtained in such role is not used in the preparation of the Product. Although Citi Research does not set a predetermined frequency for publication, if the Product is a fundamental equity or credit research report, it is the intention of Citi Research to provide research coverage of the covered issuers, including in response to news affecting the issuer. For non- fundamental research reports, Citi Research may not provide regular updates to the views, recommendations and facts included in the reports. Notwithstanding that Citi Research

maintains coverage on, makes recommendations concerning or discusses issuers, Citi Research may be periodically restricted from referencing certain issuers due to legal or policy reasons. Where a component of a published trade idea is subject to a restriction, the trade idea will be removed from any list of open trade ideas included in the Product. Upon the lifting of the restriction, the trade idea will either be re- instituted in the open trade ideas list if the analyst continues to support it or it will be officially closed. Citi Research may provide different research products and services to different classes of customers (for example, based upon long- term or short- term investment horizons) that may lead to differing conclusions or recommendations that could impact the price of a security contrary to the recommendations in the alternative research product, provided that each is consistent with the rating system for each respective product.

The securities of non- U.S. issuers may not be registered with, nor be subject to the reporting requirements of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. There may be limited information available on foreign securities. Foreign companies are generally not subject to uniform audit and reporting standards, practices and requirements comparable to those in the U.S. Securities of some foreign companies may be less liquid and their prices more volatile than securities of comparable U.S. companies. In addition, exchange rate movements may have an adverse effect on the value of an investment in a foreign stock and its corresponding dividend payment for U.S. investors. Net dividends to ADR investors are estimated, using withholding tax rates conventions, deemed accurate, but investors are urged to consult their tax advisor for exact dividend computations.
